body_text.text: • Individual's travel-related influenza risk perception and mitigation is modeled. 9 • Recent influenza experience increased perceived risk for all trips types. 10 • Risk mitigation results show that males are less likely to alter their travel plans. 11 • Persons proactive with their health are also proactive in mitigating influenza risk. 12 • Increased risk perception at work did not significantly reduce travel. Influenza is a contagious virus affecting both one's health and economic productivity. This study evaluates uses a sur-19 vey of 2168 individuals across the U.S. Ordered logit regressions are used to model risk perception and generalized 20 ordered logit regressions are used to model risk mitigation travel-related decisions. Models are estimated for three in-21 fluenza outbreak scenarios, specifically an individual's travel-related: 1) risk perceptions, 2) risk mitigation decisions 22 when infected and the individual wants to prevent spreading it, and may want treatment, and 3) risk mitigation deci-23 sions when not infected and the individual wants to reduce exposure. Risk perception results show that a recent per-24 sonal experience with influenza-like symptoms and being female significantly increased risk perception at mandatory 25 and medical trip locations. Risk mitigation model results show that males are less likely to alter their travel patterns in 26 response to the possible spreading of the virus or increasing exposure. Knowing the difference between influenza and 27 the stomach flu is more influential in reducing travel than a recent influenza experience in one's household. Individuals 28 proactive with their health (i.e., receive the vaccine, have health insurance) are also proactive in seeking medical at-29 tention and reducing influenza spread. Lastly, aligned with the Protection Motivation Theory, individuals reduce travel 30 to locations in which they perceived medium or high risk. However, increased risk perceived at one's work location did 31 not significantly reduce travel. The findings provide insight into the risk perception and mitigation behavior of the 32 American public during the COVID-19 pandemic and after restrictions are lifted. (Schoenbaum, 1987

Transportation Research Interdisciplinary Perspectives j o u r n a l h o m e p a g e : h t t p s : / / w w w . j o u r n a l s . e l s e v i e r . c o m / t r a n s p o r t a t i o n -r e s e a r c hi n t e r d i s c i p l i n a r y -p e r s p e c t i v e s in health protection behavior to avoid getting sick (Rogers, 1983; Ruthig, 95 2016). In other words, threat appraisal is the estimation of the chance of 96 contracting the disease and estimation of the seriousness of a disease 97 (i.e., severity) (Rogers, 1975 (Rogers, , 1983 Boer and Seydel, 1996) . Coping ap-98 praisal looks at the "individual's expectancy that carrying out recommenda-99 tions can remove the threat (response efficacy) and the belief in one's ability 100 to execute recommended courses of action successfully (self-efficacy)" 101 (Boer and Seydel, 1996) . Several past studies focused on connecting risk perception and risk mit-114 igation. In a study on the Australian population, Barr et al. (2008) found 115 that respondents with higher levels of health-risk perception reported 116 more willingness to comply with public health interventions during influ- The purpose of this study is to evaluate three scenarios using data from a 122 survey of 2168 individuals across the U.S. Ordered logit regressions are 123 used to model risk perception and generalized ordered logit regressions 124 are used for risk mitigation travel-related decisions. Three scenarios are 125 tested with respect to an influenza outbreak, specifically an individual's 126 travel-related: 1) risk perceptions, 2) risk mitigation decisions when in-127 fected, the individual wants to prevent spreading it, and may want treat-128 ment, and 3) risk mitigation decisions when not infected and the 129 individual wants to reduce exposure. This study adds to the existing litera-130 ture through these scenarios and the specific locations considered 131 (i.e., rather than social-distancing in general). Scenario 1 includes the loca-132 tions for work, school, restaurants, libraries, doctor's offices, and hospitals. 133 Understanding the risk perceptions of contracting influenza at these loca-134 tions may provide insights for how the public will view the risk of 135 contracting other viruses (e.g., COVID-19) when travel restrictions are 136 lifted but before vaccines are available. Scenario 2's risk mitigation models 137 pertain to visiting doctors' offices, avoiding public places, avoiding public 138 transit, and staying home. The factors identified in these models may be 139 helpful for researchers analyzing disease spread. Scenario 3's risk mitiga-140 tion models pertain to the last three locations in Scenario 2 and the factors 141 associated with these models may indicate which individuals are more 142 likely to voluntarily social-distance even when not requested by governing 143 entities.

The remainder of this paper is divided into five sections. Section 2 dis-145 cusses the data and methodology of this study. Section 3 summarizes the re-146 sults of the risk perception scenario. Section 4 contains the results from the 147 two risk mitigation scenarios. Section 5 discusses the policy implications of 148 the study's findings and Section 6 provides conclusions and recommenda-149 tions for future research. cance and, at times, the reduction resulted in variable insignificance.
When significant, the risk perception ratings were included as indepen-196 dent variables in the Scenario 2 and 3 models.

The dependent variables for all models were indicated on three-factor 198 scales (low, medium, high or never, sometimes, always). These responses 199 have an intuitive order but no mathematical equivalent representation.

The generalized ordered logit model has a similar probability equation 218 to the ordered logit. However, since the generalized ordered logit model 219 gives one coefficient to parameters meeting the parallel regression assump-220 tion and more than one coefficient to those violating the assumption, the 221 equation is adjusted to meet this specification. Eq. (1) gives the generalized 222 logit probability equation (for individual i selecting an option with a coding 223 greater than j) for a model where both X 1i and X 2i meet the parallel regres-224 sion assumption and therefore β 1 and β 2 can be used across all j's. The X 3i 225 variable did not meet the assumption, therefore β 3 varies across the j alter- (Williams, 2006) . Income/HHSize HH income in ten-thousand dollars divided by the number of members in the household

The source and type of information on influenza spread affects how peo-289 ple perceive health risks (Suciu, 2019) . Survey responses could indicate 290 more than one information source, so they were not mutually exclusive. 291 Finding out about an influenza outbreak by word of mouth increased risk 292 perception for mandatory and medical trips. However, influenza outbreak 293 information disseminated through television had a greater impact on risk 294 perception for discretionary trips than for the other two trip categories. So-295 cial media as a dissemination channel of an outbreak was also tested in each 296 of the models, but was insignificant. Other studies show that while social 297 media is increasingly used as an information source (Weber Shandwick, 298 2018), findings show people are less likely to believe the health informa-299 tion they are reading from social media compared to other channels 300 (Miraglia and Kinman, 2017). This could lead to social media's insignificant 301 ability to increase risk perception.

Results for Scenario 2 (i.e., travel-related actions when the respondent is 304 infected) are discussed in Section 4.1 and presented in Tables 3a and 3b. Re-305 sults for Scenario 3 (i.e., travel-related actions during an influenza outbreak 306 and the respondent is not infected) are discussed in Section 4.2 and pre-307 sented in Table 4 . None of the models in this section passed the parallel 308 regression assumption and, therefore, were required to use the generalized 309 ordered logit methodology.

The results show that males were less likely to prevent the spread of the 324 disease, as they were statistically less likely than females to avoid public 325 places, avoid public transit, and stay at home. This is noticeable in the mar-326 ginal effects, where male respondents were, for example, 2.89% more likely 327 to never avoid public places when experiencing influenza-like symptoms 328 compared to female respondents. Males, however, were not statistically t2:1

significantly less likely to visit the doctor and, therefore, were not any less 330 active in obtaining treatment than females. Due to this insignificance, the 331 gender variable is not included in the Visit Doctor's Office model.

For all Scenario 2 models, families with at least one child 12 years old or 333 younger did not show statistically significantly different behavior than fam-334 ilies without a child in that age range. Previous experience with influenza 335 was a statistically significant predictor of behavior for avoiding public 336 places and staying at home, where respondents with experience had a 337 high likelihood of sometimes taking each travel-related action. This 338 means that having experience with influenza decreased the chances of 339 never or always taking these actions. Also, respondents who had received 340 the vaccine and had health insurance were more likely to always visit the 341 doctor's office if infected with influenza. These findings support that people 342 who receive the annual vaccine are likely proactive about taking health 343 measures, and having access to the health insurance allowed them to obtain 344 affordable medical treatment.

Respondents who are employed were 11.42% less likely to always avoid 346 public places and 16.65% less likely to always stay at home compared to 347 those not currently employed. Similarly, respondents with a higher family 348 income per capita showed a reduced rate in taking travel-related social dis-349 tancing actions by being less likely to stay at home. The reduced rate of mit-350 igation behavior of the employed could be due to the inability to take time 351 off from work, either for financial or work policy reasons, even when in-352 fected with influenza. The frequency of presenteeism (i.e., working while 353 sick) has been analyzed in literature and it has been "estimated that em-354 ployee presenteeism is between 1.8 to 10 times more frequent than absen-355 teeism" (Suciu, 2019) . It is important to note that government regulations 356 and stay-at-home orders for non-essential personnel during the COVID-19 357 pandemic likely prevented presenteeism that was seen in previous influ-358 enza outbreaks, such as seasonal.

Also, Scenario 2 models show that respondents who had knowledge of 360 the difference between influenza and a stomach flu were more likely to 361 avoid public places and to stay home when sick with influenza compared 362 to their counterparts. Those identifying as Caucasian, non-Hispanic had de-363 creased chances of visiting a doctor's office when having influenza. Older 364 individuals were more likely to avoid transit to reduce the spread of influ-365 enza than their younger counterparts. Living in an apartment or mobile 366 home increased the chances of seeking medical attention when infected. This study contained several generalized ordered and ordered logit 472 models surrounding an individual's risk perception and travel behavior dur-473 ing an influenza outbreak. Males were statistically significantly less likely 474 than females to perceive risk as well as alter their travel patterns by volun-475 tarily social distancing in response to the possibility of spreading the dis-476 ease or increased exposure to the disease. Similarly, in Scenario 3, when 454 the individual is not infected during an influenza outbreak, individuals who 455 had at least a bachelor's degree, higher family income per capita, and/or 456 were employed were less likely to reduce travel that could increase expo-457 sure to influenza

Therefore, model results indicate low levels of self-efficacy for work 464 trips compare to other trip types. FIGREF1.text: United States, influenza affects an estimated 25-50 million 46 people per year, with 150,000 hospitalizations and 30,000-40,000 deaths 47 (Rauš et al., 2015), resulting in an annual economic impact in the billions 48 of dollars

FIGREF2.text: After perceiving a high health risk, the protective actions an individual 103 chooses are dependent on the mitigation strategies available to the individ-104 ual. Based on response efficacy and self-efficacy, an individual can either 105 adopt or reject a protective action. For example, social distancing such as 106 avoiding public places can reduce exposure to the virus, reducing the like-107 lihood of contracting influenza, while vaccination can reduce susceptibility 108 to virus strains included in the vaccine. Visiting the doctor while ill can lead 109 to treatments to reduce the severity of the symptoms. All risk mitigation ac-110 tions investigated in this paper either modify the exposure component of 111 risk for the individual or others or the severity component of the 112 consequences.

FIGREF4.text: 117 enza outbreaks. Similar results were found in Hong Kong (Leung et al., 118 2003), Italy (Di Giuseppe et al., 2008), and Australia (Jacobs et al., 119 2010), where respondents with increased perception of risk were more 120 likely to engage in risk-reducing behaviors.

FIGREF6.text: household members are recruited for the panel and assigned 157 to a study sample, they are notified by email for survey taking and panelists 158 can visit their online member page. The sample for this study consisted of 159 participants who spoke English, were at least 18 years old, and resided in 160 the United States. From the 3604 fielded participants in March 2016, a 161 total of 2168 participants (close to 60%) completed the survey. The major-162 ity of the respondents were based in California (11.2%), followed by Texas 163 (7.3%), Florida (6.7%) and New York (5.9%). 164 Survey participants were provided the following text prompt for the 165 symptoms of influenza: "The purpose of this survey is to learn about your 166 experience with influenza. Influenza is an illness that has symptoms such 167 as: fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches, runny or stuffy nose, headaches, 168 and fatigue. Influenza

FIGREF7.text: Q7is not what people refer to as the stomach flu. When169 completing this survey, please consider only influenza and not the stom-170 ach flu as you answer the questions." 171Table 1outlines the information collected from respondents that were 172 used to build the models for the three scenarios, including both the inde-173 pendent and dependent variables. Scenario 1 contains models that estimate 174 factors that influence a person's risk perception at work, school, restaurant, 175 library, hospital, and doctor office locations. Scenario 2 contains travel-176 related behaviors for four locations when a person is sick with influenza 177 and possibly trying to prevent spreading the virus or to seek medical atten-178 tion. Scenario 3 contains three models for when someone is not sick, but 179 possibly wants to reduce exposure. 180 Additional questions regarding each respondent's demographics and 181 home provided information that could be used to predict their risk per-182 ceptions and their risk mitigation actions in the three scenarios. Respon-183 dents selected their household income range and, for this study, the 184 income ranges were converted to a continuous format by averaging 185 the minimum and maximum bounds of each range. The housing type 186 (apartment/mobile) and race/ethnicity (race white, non-Hispanic) var-187 iables, respectively, were grouped to increase variable significance in 188 the models. For example, with the race/ethnicity variable, all combina-189 tions were tested, such as Black/non-Hispanic and White/non-Hispanic 190 vs Any/Hispanic and Other/non-Hispanic, Any/Hispanic and Black/ 191 non-Hispanic vs White/non-Hispanic and Other/non-Hispanic, Black/ 192 non-Hispanic vs all other races, White/non-Hispanic vs all other races, 193 etc. Other race and housing type groupings reduced variable signifi-194

FIGREF8.text: An ordered logit model is most commonly used to account for this property 201 in the dependent variable, and the ordered logit was used for Scenario 1.

FIGREF9.text: However, the difference in the transition from never to sometimes and 203 the difference from sometimes to always is not always equal. Many vari-204 ables in the Scenario 2 and 3 models had relationships that violated the par-205 allel regression assumption of the ordered logit. This was indicated through 206 the results of the Brant Test, which significantly rejected the null hypothesis 207 that the parallel regression assumption holds (Williams, 2006). This means 208 there was not a single uniform trend across the three responses. For exam-209 ple, in this study, a large number of respondents with past influenza expe-210 rience answered 'sometimes' to avoiding public places when sick while 211 very few answered 'never' or 'always.' This relationship violates the parallel 212 regression assumption. The ordered logit cannot be used because a single 213 coefficient cannot pick up this changing effect across the three ordered re-214 sponses. Therefore, the generalized ordered logit used in Scenarios 2 and 3

FIGREF11.text: people's risk perceptions were developed for select locations,241    including mandatory trips (i.e., work and school), discretionary trips 242 (i.e., restaurants and libraries), and medical trips (i.e., hospitals and doctor's 243 offices). The ordered logit methodology was used as all models passed the 244 parallel regression assumption.Table 2presents the six models, where the 245 work model was estimated only on responses from employed participants 246 and the school model on responses from households that had children 247 12 years old and younger. The McFadden pseudo-R 2 was used to indicate 248 the model goodness-of-fit, which typically has low values and should not 249 be interpreted as a linear regression R-squared value. Previous researchers 250 (Norušis, 2012; Grilli and Rampichini, 2014) using the ordered logistic re-251 gression have reported values from 0.012 to 0.075. 252 As indicated inTable 2, males significantly perceived lower risk at 253 work, school and the doctor's office. This finding is consistent with litera-254 ture where, in a review of studies related to gender and risk perception,255    Gustafsod found that while men and women are concerned about the 256 same things, women frequently worry more(Gustafsod, 1998). Davidson257 and Freudenburg suggested that the traditional gender role of women 258 being nurturers and care providers within a family could lead to higher 259 health risk perceptions (Davidson and Freudenburg, 1996).260 If the participant or someone in their household had been infected with 261 influenza in the past 6 months, that person had a heightened risk percep-262 tion at all of the locations with work having the greatest increase. This is 263 similar to the findings in Leung et al. (2003), where in the context of severe 264 acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), those with relevant symptoms were 265 more likely to take precautionary measures. 266 Employees of jobs that involve close contact with the public viewed 267 their workplaces as having higher risk. This type of employment allows 268 greater opportunities for exposure to viruses through the exhalation of in-269 fected individuals (Fabian et al., 2008) as well as coughing and sneezing. 270 Renters perceived their workplaces to have lower risk on average. Single 271 parent households on average saw the workplace as having a higher risk 272 of contracting influenza compared to non-single parent households. How-273 ever, on average, they viewed the school environment to have lower risk 274 than their counterparts. 275 Household income was indirectly related to perceived risk for discre-276 tionary trips. This indirect relationship is consistent with other literature 277 that found that higher income individuals/households were more capable 278 of making purchases to reduce their risk (Dosman et al., 2001). Those living 279 in a metropolitan area perceived higher risk at the library compared to 280 those not living in a metropolitan area. Those with children 12 years old 281 and younger did not have significantly different risk perceptions for work 282 and discretionary trip locations, but did view medical locations as having 283 higher risk. This may be due to children having immature immune systems 284 compared to adults, where immunity memory is established during the first 285 18 years of a person's life (Dietert et al., 2000). Also, having knowledge of 286 the difference between influenza and the stomach flu increased risk percep-287 tion at hospitals.

FIGREF14.text: and 3b present the results for visiting the doctor, avoiding 312 public places, avoiding public transit, and staying home in Scenario 2. In 313 the 'Visit Doctor's Office' model, the Race White (non-Hispanic) variable 314 did not meet the parallel regression assumption and, therefore has different 315 coefficients and trends change across the marginal effects percentages. That 316 is, self-identified Caucasian, non-Hispanics were 3.65% more likely to re-317 spond 'Never' to visiting the doctor when sick compared to other races/eth-318 nicities, 4.27% more likely to respond 'Sometimes,' and 7.92% less likely to 319 respond 'Always.' This trend increases then decreases across the ordered re-320 sponses. In the same model, the Vaccine variable did pass the parallel re-321 gression assumption, causing both of the variable's coefficients to be 322 equal at 0.573.

FIGREF15.text: 4 presents the generalized ordered logit model results for Sce-369 nario 3, which includes the same travel-related actions as Scenario 2 with 370 the exception of visiting the doctor as the respondent is not infected in 371 this scenario and does not need to seek medical attention. Similar to the 372 findings in Scenario 2, males were less likely to avoid public places and to 373 stay at home to reduce exposure to influenza. However, males were much 374 less likely to take action when already infected compared to women (Sce-375 nario 2) than when not infected (Scenario 3). Across all models in both sce-376 narios, having a child younger than 12 years old in the household was only377 statistically significant in avoiding public places in Scenario 3. Having chil-378 dren in the household reduces one's ability to avoid public places when they 379 are not sick. This could be due to obligations that the caregiver or other chil-380 dren in the household cannot get out of easily as well as the necessary er-381 rands a caretaker needs to make. Neither knowledge nor experience 382 statistically significantly impacted a person's travel-related risk mitigation. 383 Risk perception was significant in all three models. Respondents were more 384 likely to avoid public places and stay at home if there was increased per-385 ceived risk in stores and more likely to avoid transit when there is increased 386 risk perceived of contracting influenza in the transit system. However, re-387 spondents perceiving medium or high risk of contracting influenza at 388 work were less likely to stay at home. This may be reasonable since em-389 ployees may only be able to miss work when they are actually sick 390 themselves. 391 In Scenario 2, household income per capita, self-identifying as Cauca-392 sian, non-Hispanic, and employment are indirectly related to taking action 393 to prevent the spread when infected and the respondent's age was directly 394 related to taking action. These indirect and direct relationships are also 395 seen in Scenario 3's results with trying to reduce exposure to influenza. 396 This suggests that people who take travel-related actions when infected 397 with influenza to prevent the spread are more likely to take travel-related 398 actions to prevent getting infected during an influenza outbreak.399Also, the significant variables in Scenario 3's models show that respon-400 dents with a higher education (i.e., at least a bachelor's degree) were less 401 likely to stay at home to reduce exposure during an influenza outbreak. Sin-402 gle individuals (i.e., divorced, never married, or widowed) were more403 likely to avoid transit compared to their married counterparts, while 404 those living in a metropolitan area were less likely to stay home. In general, 405 findings from both Scenarios 2 and 3 support that wealthier and educated 406 respondents (i.e., high household income per capita, are employed, and 407 have at least a bachelor's degree) were less likely to reduce travel in re-408 sponse to influenza. This is evident from the statistical significance of the 409 Income/HHSize, BS Degree, and Working variables. Specifically, in Sce-410 nario 2 high household income per capita was statistically significantly 411 linked to less likely staying at home and those employed were less likely 412 to avoid public places and stay at home. In Scenario 3, a high household in-413 come per capita was linked to respondents being less likely to avoid public 414 places, avoid public transit, and stay at home. Those with a bachelor's t4:1

FIGREF16.text: flu (before the survey) was more effective in reducing travel 485 (avoiding public places and staying home) when the respondent is already 486 sick than having experience with influenza in one's household in the last six 487 months. Individuals who were proactive about taking care of their health 488 (i.e., received annual vaccines and had health insurance coverage) were 489 also proactive in reducing their exposure and spread of influenza. Lastly, 490 in alignment with the Protection Motivation Theory, in general, individuals 491 tended to reduce travel to locations in which they perceived medium or 492 high risk of contracting influenza, such as stores. However, perception of in-493 creased risk at work locations did not show an increased likelihood to stay 494 home. 495 Future research in this area could combine the findings from this study 496 with agent-based models that track individual's travel participation and re-497 sponses to virus outbreaks. This could lead to more refined estimates of 498 transmission and levels of exposure. The effectiveness of workplace poli-499 cies, other location specific policies, government orders, and general inter-500 ventions may be tested with such models. 501 Additional studies could look more into the link between information 502 channel and risk perception, including a validation and more in-depth anal-503 ysis of why the effectiveness of information channels changes by trip type. 504 Also, this link should be analyzed under several situations. Specifically, in 505 this study, social media was found to be insignificant while word of 506 mouth and television was significant. However, given that COVID-19 re-507 quired social distancing and quarantine measures, it would be interesting 508 to see if a person's reduced ability to get word of mouth information 509 about a trip's risk meant other channels became more significant, such as 510 social media. Lastly, future studies on the COVID-19 pandemic could eval-511 uate the effects of telecommuting and e-learning options on travelwas supported in part by the National Institutes of Health 515 Grant number 1R01GM109718.

TABREF0.text: ). Three types of influenza affect human health: seasonal, Zoonotic or variant, and pandemic influenza (WHO, 2014). Seasonal influenza can affect individuals multiple times in their lifetimes and is predominant during winter months, in regions with a temperate climate. Zoonotic or variant forms of influenza are spread by the interaction between humans and animals and have been recorded several times in the past century (WHO, 2014). Whereas, a virus is pandemic when it has not previously circulated amongst humans and creates signifi-Chappell, 2020). Pandemics can lead to much higher death tolls worldwide if not contained quickly through social distancing measures and vaccines. Influenza spreads from person to person through sneezing, coughing 62 (Stelzer-Braid et al., 2009 Q6 ), or touching contaminated surfaces (Jones, 2011). COVID-19 can live on surfaces for several days (Gray, 2020) and be airborne for up to three hours (Harvard Medical School, 2020). Individuals can be exposed to the virus at a variety of locations based on their daily activities, such as work, school, restaurants, libraries, hospitals, and doctor's offices. Seasonal influenza vaccinations are developed based on predictions of which virus strains will be prevalent in a given year, but the effectiveness varies, meaning those who are vaccinated can become ill after exposure to a strain that is not well matched by the vaccine or if the individuals are unable to develop a protective immune response. Chances of contracting or spreading the infection can be reduced if a person alters their behavior effectively when they perceive high influenza risk during their daily activities. For the purposes of this paper, risk is a combination of consequences and likelihood. The consequences are contracting influenza and the severity of the symptoms, which are a function of individual health and mitigation measures. The likelihood can be considered a function of exposure and susceptibility. The influenza virus is a threat to an individual's health if he/she is not immune. Previous studies have linked the preventative health measures an individual takes with the risk perceived (Marathe et al., 2011; Chen et al., 2010; Chai et al., 2010). For example, the Health Belief Model, a theoretical Transportation Research Interdisciplinary Perspectives xxx (xxxx) xxx ⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: shotle3@vt.edu. (S.
